episodes.title: 1581: Alike and Different
episodes.plot: Rogers attends a show full of antique cars. In the Neighborhood of Make-Believe, Mayor Maggie and Queen Sara agree to change jobs for a day.

episodes.title: 1582: Alike and Different
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers shows books in different languages. In Make-Believe, the Queen and Mayor are trading places, dressing in each other's clothes and learning about each other's jobs. Mister Rogers helps children know that "everyone is fancy."

episodes.title: 1583: Alike and Different
episodes.plot: Robert Trow dresses up in his Bob Dog costume so that Rogers can compare a real hound to a man in a dog costume. In the Neighborhood of Make-Believe, everyone, except Prince Tuesday, knows Mayor Maggie and Queen Sara will trade places for a day. This leads to the inevitable misunderstanding.

episodes.title: 1584: Alike and Different
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers brings a clown mask and talks about clowns. There are visiting clowns In Make-Believe, too. Queen Sara and Mayor Maggie learned a lot about each other from switching jobs, but decide they're happier in their own jobs.

episodes.title: 1585: Alike and Different
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers and Betty Aberlin visit the circus to see acrobats, elephants and tigers. They go backstage to watch a clown put on his make up. In Make-Believe, Daniel's friends help him overcome his fear of clowns and other costumes.

episodes.title: 1586: Nighttime
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers pretends it's nighttime, turns out lights and pulls out his sofa bed. He shows there are no "monsters" under the bed and has a video of how people make flashlights. In Make-Believe, nighttime brings lots of feelings.

episodes.title: 1587: Nighttime
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers and puppet Daniel Tiger visit Moscow and appear on Russia's nighttime children's television program "Good Night, Little Ones." In Make-Believe, Lady Elaine is scaring Daniel Tiger with her talk about falling stars.

episodes.title: 1588: Nighttime
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers puts on a scuba diver's mask and snorkel. In Make-Believe, Henrietta is scared by someone in a mask because she can't see his face. Mister Rogers also puts on a firefighter's mask and uniform to help children with their fears.

episodes.title: 1589: Nighttime
episodes.plot: The host of a Russian children's show visits with her puppet and a video of how people make Matrouska dolls, wooden dolls that "nest" inside each other. In Make-Believe, an unusual nighttime visitor, a spaceman, arrives from the sky.

episodes.title: 1590: Nighttime
episodes.plot: Mr. McFeely shows a video of different people doing their jobs at night. Dawn nears in the Neighborhood of Make-Believe and still no one can understand the night visitor.

episodes.title: 1591: Kindness and Unkindness
episodes.plot: Two factory tours: How people make harmonicas and how people make garden hoes. In Make-Believe, the King reacts unkindly. He also sends for a royal tutor, worried his son isn't learning enough in school by singing songs and playing.

episodes.title: 1592: Kindness and Unkindness
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers takes a trip through Luray Caverns where he and a blind saxophonist play music. In Make-Believe, King Friday looks for a tutor for his son and is working on being kind. Mister Rogers talks about the importance of teachers.

episodes.title: 1593: Kindness and Unkindness
episodes.plot: Mister Rogers learns some fancy jump ropes trick and reminds us that exercise is a way to be kind to our bodies. In Make-Believe, Prince Tuesday talks bravely to his father who wants to take him out of school to learn with a private tutor.

episodes.title: 1594: Kindness and Unkindness
episodes.plot: Mr. McFeely brings a videotape of how bicycle helmets are made. The Neighborhood of Make-Believe is surprised to see "Sir Thomas T. Tune".

episodes.title: 1595: Kindness and Unkindness
episodes.plot: In Make-Believe, Broadway star Tommy Tune delights everyone with his dancing -- and with his kindness when he receives a gift that doesn't fit. Mister Rogers talks about being polite as one way to be kind, and an accordion player visits.
